questions.question: How do Mrs. Jones and Roger meet?

choices.answer: He tries to snatch her purse
She invites him into her home.
He robs the shop where she works.
She offers to buy him a pair of shoes.
He thinks she will kidnap him.
He thinks she will hurt him.
He thinks she will turn him in to the police.
He thinks she will tell his parents what he did.

questions.question: What is the FIRST thing Mrs. Jones tells Roger to do?

choices.answer: eat dinner
wash his face
behave himself
go buy some milk

questions.question: Why does Mrs. Jones say that she wishes Roger were her son?

choices.answer: so she could punish him properly
so she could teach him right from wrong
so she could buy him all the shoes he wanted
so she could make sure he gets a good education

questions.question: What similarity between Roger and Mrs. Jones does she mention?

choices.answer: They are both poor.
They both want suede shoes.
They have both hurt people they loved.
They have both done things they aren't proud of.

questions.question: At the end of the story, Roger wanted to say something more but he couldn't. Why not?

choices.answer: He still hasn't learned any manners.
He is upset that she wants him to leave.
He doesn't really need the money she gave him.
He can't think of words to express his gratitude.

questions.question: What can readers infer about Roger's life?

choices.answer: His family has money for shoes.
His parents left him on the street.
He usually has to take care of himself.
He spends a lot of time at the city jail.

questions.question: Which passage best supports the answer for the last question?

choices.answer: "I'm very sorry, lady..." whispered the boy.
"There's nobody home at my house," said the boy.
"You gonna take me to jail?"
"Do you need somebody to go to the store?" he asked.

questions.question: What is her main hope for Roger?

choices.answer: She wants Roger to feel miserable.
She wants him to become her son.
She wants him to feel trustworthy.
She wants him to return her money.

questions.question: Which is part of the story's exposition?

choices.answer: He looked as if he was fourteen, frail and willow-wild.
She heated some lima beans and ham and set the table.
When she got to the door, she dragged him inside.
There was a very long pause. He dried his face.

questions.question: Why is that passage part of the exposition?

choices.answer: It describes Roger using adjectives.
It shows how they made peace.
It creates tension between them.
It gives background info about Roger.

questions.question: Which event creates tension in the story?

choices.answer: Mrs. Jones walks down the street.
Mrs. Jones drags Roger to her home.
Mrs. Jones heats up food for supper.
Mrs. Jones tells Roger about her job.

questions.question: Mrs. Rogers was keeping Roger there. The door was open and he could leave! But he didn't.

choices.answer: This heightens the reader's fear.
This points ahead to the outcome of the story.
This creates a sense of satisfaction in the reader.
This draws attention to a turning point in the story.

questions.question: Why does the reader have a sense of satisfaction at the end of the story?

choices.answer: Mrs. Jones has gotten revenge on the boy.
She will probably never have to see him again.
Roger will start a new life as Mrs. Jones' son.
Roger has learned that he can be trusted.

questions.question: What does the word SQUARE mean in this sentence: The pitcher looked him square in the eye?

choices.answer: fairly
in the center
well deserved
having four sides
set the plate
on the table
took a seat
telling stories
we
sometimes
from
strangers
